title: Identification and Authentication
description: Verifying the identity of users, processes, and devices

questions.question: Does each user have a unique username/ID?
questions.context: No shared accounts like 'admin' or 'office'. Each person needs their own login.
questions.examples: firstname.lastname format, employee ID, no generic accounts
questions.followUp: Are there any shared accounts currently? How are accounts named?
assessmentObjectives: No shared or group accounts exist

questions.question: Do you verify user identity before granting access (passwords, MFA)?
questions.context: Users must prove who they are. Passwords are minimum, MFA is better.
questions.examples: Windows login, password requirements, multi-factor authentication
questions.followUp: What are your password requirements? Is MFA enabled?

questions.question: Do you use multi-factor authentication (MFA)?
questions.context: MFA requires something you know (password) plus something you have (phone/token) or are (fingerprint).
questions.examples: SMS codes, authenticator apps, hardware tokens, biometrics
questions.followUp: What MFA methods are used? For all users or just some? Any exceptions?
questions.discussion: Multi-factor authentication provides increased assurance that users are who they claim to be. It significantly reduces account compromise risk.

questions.question: Do privileged accounts use MFA?
questions.context: Admin accounts absolutely must have MFA - they're high-value targets.
questions.examples: Admin MFA required, no exceptions for administrators, privileged access management
questions.followUp: Do ALL admin accounts have MFA? Any service accounts without it?
questions.discussion: Privileged accounts have elevated access and require stronger authentication. MFA for these accounts is critical.

questions.question: Do you replay-resistant authentication for network access?
questions.context: Authentication should prevent captured credentials from being reused.
questions.followUp: What prevents credential replay attacks? How are sessions protected?
questions.discussion: Replay-resistant mechanisms prevent captured authentication data from being reused to gain unauthorized access.

questions.question: Do you disable accounts after a period of inactivity?
questions.context: Unused accounts are security risks - they should be automatically disabled.
questions.examples: 90-day inactivity disables account, quarterly account reviews, automated deactivation
questions.followUp: When are inactive accounts disabled? How do you identify them? What's the process?
questions.discussion: Inactive accounts provide unnecessary attack surface. Automatic disabling ensures unused accounts can't be exploited.

questions.question: Do you enforce minimum password complexity?
questions.context: Passwords need to be strong enough to resist guessing and cracking.
questions.examples: 12+ characters, upper/lower/number/special, no dictionary words, no reuse
questions.followUp: What are the password requirements? How are they enforced? Any exceptions?
questions.discussion: Password complexity requirements make passwords harder to guess or crack. Length is more important than complexity.

questions.question: Do you prohibit password reuse?
questions.context: Users shouldn't cycle through the same passwords repeatedly.
questions.examples: Remember last 24 passwords, minimum age before change, no common passwords
questions.followUp: How many passwords are remembered? Can users change back immediately?
questions.discussion: Password reuse restrictions prevent users from alternating between a small set of passwords, maintaining better security over time.

questions.question: Do you encrypt passwords in storage and transmission?
questions.context: Passwords must be protected both when saved and when sent over networks.
questions.examples: Hashed passwords, TLS/SSL for transmission, no plain text storage
questions.followUp: How are passwords stored? Are they encrypted in transit? Any legacy systems?
questions.discussion: Cryptographic protection of passwords prevents their disclosure if systems are compromised or network traffic intercepted.

questions.question: Do you use temporary passwords that must be changed?
questions.context: Initial or reset passwords should be temporary and require immediate change.
questions.examples: Force change on first login, temporary password expires, unique initial passwords
questions.followUp: What happens with new accounts? How are passwords reset? Must they be changed?
questions.discussion: Temporary passwords ensure users create their own unique passwords and prevent default passwords from remaining active.

questions.question: Do you obscure feedback during authentication?
questions.context: Passwords shouldn't be visible when typed, and errors shouldn't reveal valid usernames.
questions.examples: Password masking, generic error messages, no username confirmation
questions.followUp: Are passwords hidden when typed? What do error messages say? Any information leakage?
questions.discussion: Obscuring authentication feedback prevents shoulder surfing and username enumeration attacks.
